body:
Of course. I did a make clean each time. Then a make -j8. And then python setup.py install, which generates this module mxnet-0.9.5-py2.7.egg.

In the code, python confirms that i have the good mxnet version:
print (mx.__version__) = 0.9.5
Maybe the reason is the parameter 'setTimeout' of class MXNet  is set to be smaller.

Thanks for the reply. But what about cases when I don't have an *image* as input? My input is just a 500 dimensional vector. (the 500L above). In that case, the input fully connected layer
` net = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data = net, name='fc1',num_hidden=100)`

should be able to take care of this right? It is already flattened so I do not have to use the `mx.sym.Flatten()` function . 

In the MNIST case, the flatten() function takes an image of size `1 x 28 x 28` and returns a vector of length `784`

Thanks Eric. The C BLAS function signatures are uniform across all libs. However when it comes to the C LAPACK interface, vecLib, ATLAS support the dated CLAPACK interface (direct translation of the Fortran interface to C); NetLib, MKL, OpenBLAS support the newer LAPACKE interface. Therefore I may need to modify the global `Makefile` to define macro corresponding to the exact BLAS/LAPACK lib in use?

Example of `dposv` (linear solver for symmetric, semi-positive A):

Under CLAPACK interface, 

```c
int dposv_(char *__uplo, 
        __CLPK_integer *__n, __CLPK_integer *__nrhs,
        __CLPK_doublereal *__a, __CLPK_integer *__lda, 
        __CLPK_doublereal *__b, __CLPK_integer *__ldb,
        __CLPK_integer *__info);
``` 

Under LAPACKE interface,

```c
lapack_int LAPACKE_dposv (int matrix_layout, char uplo, 
        lapack_int n, lapack_int nrhs, 
        double * a, lapack_int lda, 
        double * b, lapack_int ldb);
```

The linker cannot find the libraries to link your final shared object against.  Because either:

1. you have not installed them in your system, or
2. the path where they are installed is not visible to the linker.

Do you have those libraries?  To start off you can try build with  `USE_OPENCV = 0` and also add the path to your openblas installation for eg: `ADD_LDFLAGS=-L../../OpenBLAS` in your `config.mk`

we have swapaxes for this

`swapaxis` and `moveaxis` are different: the former one swaps the position of two dimensions while the latter moves one axis from one position to another. 
I am using the same naming convention as NumPy which offers both `swapaxes` and `moveaxes`.

This one is faster when multiple GPUs are available. 
I got like 15fps/37fps/43fps with the old cv2, mx.image(3 threads) and det_iter.cc(3 threads) on a single GPU, respectively. 
The gap is even larger on multi-gpu and more threads, obviously.

Here's my solution. (CentOS 7)

1. Edit Makefile.config (line 54-55)
BLAS_INCLUDE := /usr/include/atlas
BLAS_LIB := /usr/lib64/atlas

2. Change Makefile (line 384)
LIBRARIES += cblas atlas 
==>
LIBRARIES += satlas tatlas

@charleslipku @d4wud 
The solution is rename mxnet/amalgamation/jni_libmxnet_predict.so to libmxnet_predict.so
Do not use mxnet/lib/libmxnet_predict.so

What's more, link  with  -static-libstdc++
LDFLAGS+= -L${OPENBLAS_ROOT} -L${OPENBLAS_ROOT}/lib -static-libstdc++ 

the output is about 13.5 MB
The other steps is at
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/4783

The "invalid device function" error suggests you do not generate the code for the proper GPU compute capability. I don't have experience with Visual Studio, but somewhere in the configuration you should be able to set compute capabilities for which to generate the code. If your TitanX is Maxwell it should be 5.2, if Pascal, then it should be 6.1
@cjolivier01 I searched for possible solution: what you are probably missing is the cufft.lib in your linker input. (in VS: Project Properties->Linker->Input->Additional Dependencies

please fix gpu test

@piiswrong 

Thanks for your reply.

My question is why softMax layer took too much CPU utilization than MLP+softMax layer ? 

SoftMax: I mean here is using SoftMax layer without any network layer ( hidden layer )
Code:
`
data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
flatten = mx.sym.Flatten(data=data)
fc3 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = flatten, name='fc3', num_hidden=num_classes)

mlp = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc3, name = 'softmax')
`

MLP: I mean here is using SoftMax layer with network layer ( hidden layer )

data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
flatten = mx.sym.Flatten(data=data)
fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = flatten, name='fc1', num_hidden=512)
act1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc1, name='relu1', act_type="relu")
fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act1, name = 'fc2', num_hidden = 256)
act2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data = fc2, name='relu2', act_type="relu")
fc3 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = act2, name='fc3', num_hidden=num_classes)
mlp = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data = fc3, name = 'softmax')



Based on my understanding from different framework, CPU is increasing while I am increasing layers.
it does not make sense for me to use 80 % of CPU for doing SoftMax layer while 40% for SoftMax and MLP layers. 

Sincerely
I wouldn't stress over performance numbers on these small networks. Try resnet to get realistic performance measure

I'm planning to do the same work and has a simple design like follows
```
include
|---mxnet
|---|---module.h
src
|---module
|---|---base_module.h/.cc
|---|---bucket_module.h/.cc
|---|---module.cc
|---c_api
|---|---c_module_api.h
```
BaseModule provides a Reshape interface
BucketModule handles bucket models like lstm, using a single subgraph/executor.
By the way, since some packages(ps-lite/python/...) are not needed in inference phase, will it be better to provide a branch for production with less dependency?

Can we call it module to be consistent?
